participant_abstract.sent: New information was provided by the project manager: top priorities are: to deliver the product at low design cost for maximum profit in the minimum amount of time; the corporate logo must be displayed and a teletext function is not required.
Presentations were given by all departments.
The materials and operation of the remote was discussed and the need for a user-friendly design.
Marketing revealed that people are frustrated with losing the remote and with having to learn complicated functions.
A clapping-response device to find lost remotes was chosen, and a hidden panel for extra functions was decided so that no complicated menus have to be used while keeping the remote sleek and modern.
The younger generation are open to voice recognition, but the older generation do not like the idea, it was decided that this is too complex for the timeframe and budget.
The primary and secondary (hidden) buttons were discussed.

participant_actions.sent: Project manager - write minutes, prepare presentation.
User-interface designer - research new information and prepare presentation.
Industrial designer - research new information and prepare presentation.
Market researcher - research new information and prepare presentation.

participant_decisions.sent: Two seperate displays on remote: primary - numbers 0-9, channel up/down, volume up/down and mute, standby.
Hidden buttons - brightness up/down, contrast up/down, tuner up/down. corporate logo/colour scheme needs to be displayed.
Clapping response function to find lost remote.

participant_problems.sent: Speech recognition too complex and doesn't appeal to whole market - do not include.
Environmental issues of standby: adverse impact of prolonged standby but would not be as marketable without this function, keep button, possibly make smaller.
